Award.AwardTitle: III-COR: Collaborative Classification of Large, Growing Collections with Evolving Facets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
IIS - 0713290
Wu, Harris
Old Dominion University Research Foundation
III-COR ollaborative Classification of Large, Growing Collections

This proposal addresses the problem of exploring large digital collections or primarily non-textual content to make them more useable and useful, by allowing users to collectively develop a faceted classification system and then to populate the schema (system). The proposal seeks to implement this collaborative classification system on a subset of the federated US Government Photographs and Multimedia Collection, and then to perform a series of comprehensive evaluation activities that look at various indicators of success for the project. The primary contributions of the project are expected to be new user interfaces, open source tools, algorithms and schemes for automated classification. These resources will be made available for use by others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many multimedia collections have grown so large that it is difficult to browse or search them.  For example, the US Government Photo Multimedia Collection is a large federated multimedia collection containing some of the nation’s most precious multimedia documents. The current federation is practically inaccessible in terms of searching or browsing objects across multiple collections, as many collections contain images or other multimedia objects with few textual descriptive data (metadata) attached to them. In this project we have demonstrated that it is possible to use the combined efforts of the community to organize a large collection to facilitate searching and browsing.

 

We have built a system that improves access to a large, growing collection by supporting users to build a faceted (i.e., multi-perspective) classification schema collaboratively. A facet is an attribute dimension to describe items from a particular perspective. For example, in a collection of images on American History, “state” can be one facet. Other facets may include “time”, “events”, etc. These different facets allow users to navigate or search the collection from different perspectives. The system not only allows users to collaboratively build the facet structure and classify documents, but also automatically classifies documents into the evolving facet schema. We have developed algorithms in the areas of document classification, schema enrichment, cleansing and ordering.

 

We have shown the efficacy of our approach by applying our methods to several test beds. For example, we evaluated the system on an African American History Image Collection by setting up controlled experiments in four different courses at the Old Dominion University with hundreds of students. Our research indicates that students when given the opportunity will contribute in a sustainable fashion to the classification effort, which not only helps them in their study and research but also helps others. Through this collaborative approach, disadvantaged students and others who typically do not voice their opinions are given the opportunity to organize the image collection.

 

One major issue identified in the deployment and evaluation was scalability. Traditional computing cannot support ever-increasing number of users, documents, schema objects, schema history, and automated classification processes without difficult, expensive and time-consuming resource reconfiguration. To address this problem we migrated our system from a Linux-based technology stack to a cloud-based Microsoft Windows Azure platform, and exposed the system to the public as a collaborative cloud service. For the user interface we have explored scale issues such as how to manage a large number of personal schemas and historic views of metadata. On the server side we improved the system architecture for load balancing and cloud deployment. Cloud computing has enabled the Collaborative Faceted Classification System to scale virtually unlimited.
